LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of Armenia 
 
Proposal   The proposal comprises two program loans, totaling $80 million 
equivalent,  in  various  currencies  from  the  Asian  Development 
Fund (ADF) resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
help Armenia mitigate the impact of the global financial crisis by 
adopting fiscal stimulus and social safety net measures. The loans 
will help the Government of Armenia (the Government) maintain 
its core public expenditure program.

Rationale and  After growing at an average of 13.5% in 2006–2007, Armenian 
Description  economy moderated with a real gross domestic product (GDP) 
growth of 6.8% in 2008. It declined by 9.7% in the first 4 months of 
2009 and is expected to decelerate by around 9.5% in 2009. 
Remittances, which at $1.5 billion accounted for 13% of GDP in 
2008,  are  projected  to  be  around  30%  less  this  year.  The 
Armenian  dram  (AMD)  has  depreciated  25%  against  the  US 
dollar, significant since 70% of the economy is dollarized. The 
Government faces a revenue shortfall of 22% and a financing gap 
of $460 million. The fiscal deficit is estimated to increase from 
AMD40  billion  (1.0%  of  GDP),  forecast  in  the  original  2009 
budget, to 6.5% of GDP. Unemployment has been increasing and 
is likely to further rise sharply. The crisis could reverse much of 
the gains made by Armenia in reducing its poverty incidence from 
55.1%  in  1999  to  22.7%  in  2008.  Without  fiscal  support,  the 
Government  will  be  unable  to  maintain  its  core  public 
expenditures, and recover and sustain growth.

ii   
Special Features  The proposed Crisis Recovery Support Program (the Program) 
will enable the Government to mitigate the adverse impact of the 
global financial crisis. The Program is anchored on the Stand-By 
Arrangement (SBA) with the International Monetary Fund (IMF), 
which provides the overall framework for macroeconomic stability 
and  structural  reform.  Further,  the  Government’s  own  crisis 
mitigation  plan  will  be  the  public  expenditure  anchor  for  the 
support from ADB. The Program has been formulated in close 
consultation  with  the  Government  and  after  an  assessment  of 
crisis impact and fiscal needs. It is part of a well-coordinated and 
concerted  donor  effort  to  respond  to  the  Government’s  urgent 
request for budget support. 
 
Period of Utilization  The  loan  proceeds  are  expected  to  be  fully  used  by 
31 December 2009.  
 
Executing and  The  Ministry  of  Finance  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.  The 
Implementing Agencies  Ministry of Economy will be the Implementing Agency, responsible 
for  monitoring  the  implementation  of  the  Program  outcome, 
outputs and targets. 
 
Tranching  The two loans will be disbursed in a single tranche once they take 
effect. 
   
Financing Plan  The Government has requested a loan of $80 million equivalent 
from ADF resources. The Program will comprise two loans totaling 
$80  million  equivalent.  The  split  into  two  loans  is  due  to  the 
availability of ADF resources for Armenia. The first loan will be of 
$46.3  million  equivalent  financed  from  ADB’s  Special  Funds 
resources, with an annual interest rate of 1% during the grace 
period and 1.5% thereafter; a term of 24 years including a grace 
period of 8 years; and other terms and conditions substantially in 
accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  loan  agreement.  The 
second  loan  of  $33.7  million  equivalent  will  be  financed  from 
ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an annual interest rate of 
1.6% during the entire term of 24 years, including a grace period 
of 8 years, and other terms and conditions set forth in the program 
loan agreement.

iii
Procurement and  The foreign currency proceeds from the loans will be used to pay 
Disbursement  for items procured in ADB member countries, other than the items 
specified  in  the  negative  list  of  ineligible  items  and  imports 
financed from other bilateral and multilateral sources. 
 
The proceeds of the loans will be disbursed according to ADB’s 
simplification  of  disbursement  procedures  and  related 
requirements for program loans. Loan proceeds disbursed against 
imports will require a certificate from the Government stipulating 
that the value of the total imports of Armenia, minus its imports 
from  nonmember  countries,  ineligible  imports,  and  imports 
financed under other official development assistance, is at least 
equal  to  the  amount  of  the  loans  to  be  disbursed  during  a 
particular year. ADB reserves the right to audit the use of the loan 
proceeds to verify the accuracy of the Government’s certification. 
 
Counterpart Funds  The Government shall ensure that the local currency generated 
  from  the  proceeds  of  the  loans  is  used  mainly  to  
(i) compensate in part for the large revenue shortfall and enable 
the Government to maintain its core public expenditure program 
(salaries and essential social services); and (ii) make possible 
public expenditures and investments that will provide safety nets 
and create jobs. 
 
Benefits   The Program will help the Government cushion and mitigate the 
adverse impact of the crisis. It will benefit the poor and support 
efforts to protect the gains made by the Government in reducing 
poverty. It will enable the Government to 
 
(i)  maintain its core public expenditure program without any 
further cuts over and above adjustments already made; 
(ii)  meet its social safety net spending needs; and 
(iii)  create at least 6,500 new jobs by the end of 2009.  
 
Risks and Assumptions  Risks: 
 
(i)  Worsening of the global financial crisis—or its continuation 
for  a  period  longer  than  anticipated—could  hinder  the 
Government’s economic recovery plans. 
(ii)  Any political changes could alter the Government’s ability 
to implement anti-crisis measures. 
 
Assumptions: 
 
(i)  Macroeconomic  reforms  supported  under  the  IMF  SBA 
remain on track 
(ii)  Development partners provide timely and adequate budget 
support and technical assistance. 
(iii)  All projects are initiated and completed as planned.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on the proposed 
program  loans  to  the  Republic  of  Armenia  for  the  Crisis  Recovery  Support  Program  (the 
Program).1  
II.  RECENT MACROECONOMIC PERFORMANCE  
2.  Pre-Crisis Economic Performance. Armenia is a small, open economy that relies 
heavily on  remittances, foreign investment, and imports.  With real gross domestic product 
(GDP) increasing yearly by an average of more than 10% (Table 1), Armenia has been a stable 
and strong performer in the region. Much of the recent growth was fueled by the construction 
and mining sectors. The share of construction in GDP increased from 9% in 2001 to 23% in 
2008.  Remittances  and  capital  inflows  sustained  the  construction  boom,  while  increasing 
international commodity prices helped the mining sector. Remittances also boosted domestic 
consumption.

4.  Moderate  Inflation.  Inflation  accelerated  from  4.4%  in  2007  to  9.0%  in  2008,  or 
significantly above the Government’s target of 4.0% plus or minus 1.5%. In the first half of 2008, 
record prices of food and energy were the main culprits. Year-on-year inflation peaked at 11.5% 
in  August  2008  before  moderating  to  5.2%  in  December 2008  and  declining  to  3.1%  in 
April 2009 year-on-year.  
 
5.    Strong Commitment to Reform. Armenia has embarked on an ambitious set of 
reforms, including stimulating competition among enterprises, improvement of the business and 
investment  climate,  deepening  of  financial  intermediation,  reform  of  tax  policy  and  tax 
administration,  public  sector  modernization,  regional  development,  termination  of  poorly 
targeted subsidies,3 and program budgeting and public financial management. Reflecting the 
progress of reforms in some of these areas, Armenia was ranked 44th in the World Bank’s 
Doing Business survey of 2009.  
III.  IMPACT OF GLOBAL FINANCIAL CRISIS 
6.  Armenia among the Worst-Affected Countries in the Region. Armenia has felt the 
impact of the global economic crisis mainly because of the slowdown in the Russian Federation, 
the source of more than 75% of remittances to Armenia and more than 70% of foreign direct 
investment (FDI) in the country. Table 2 presents the medium-term macroeconomic outlook for 
Armenia. Measured in terms of real GDP growth, Armenia has been the worst-affected country 
in the region.

8.  Construction Slowdown. Construction, a major driving force behind Armenia’s robust 
economic growth in recent years, slowed as the demand for apartments and offices weakened. 
Since most FDI was channeled into construction, the sharp falloff in FDI since April 2008, 
combined with the reduction in demand, slashed construction activity by 31% in the second half 
of 2008. In the first quarter of 2009, value creation in the sector was down by 22% compared 
with the same period in 2008.

affected by the global economic slowdown. Slack demand for metals dramatically lowered the 
prices  of  copper  and  molybdenum  ores,4  and  triggered  the  layoff  of  hundreds  of  sector

11.  Falling Revenues. Government revenues, which had risen steadily in recent years 
(Table 1), have fallen even more steeply than real GDP. The Government had assumed 9.2% 
GDP growth when projecting revenues. In fact, revenue collections fell by 16.7% in the first 
quarter of 2009 (compared with the first quarter of 2008). The drop of 20.1% in VAT collections 
and 15.9% in profit tax collections in the first quarter, year-on-year, has been the most extreme.

The Government now expects revenue collections to be 13%–15% lower in 2009 than in 2008, 
missing the budget target by around 28%. 
 
12.  Large Budget Deficit and Financing Gap. Barring an unexpected, rapid reversal of the 
sharp deterioration in the economy and in tax revenues since last quarter of  2008, it is clear 
that the Government budget deficit for 2009 will far exceed the AMD40 billion ($105 million; 1% 
of GDP) forecast when the budget was adopted by Parliament in November 2008. As forecast 
by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), 9.5% decline in GDP, with government revenues 
declining  by  6.7%  year-on-year  from  2008  to  2009  with  corresponding  adjustments  in 
expenditure would increase the budget deficit to AMD217 billion ($564 million), or 6.5% of GDP, 
and create a financing gap of $460 million (Table 3). The budget deficit and the corresponding 
financing  gap  would  be  significantly  larger  if  the  revenues  were  to  decline  further  and 
expenditure suspensions were not made by the Government.

13.  Projected Impact of the Financial Crisis on Poverty. As the financial crisis deepens 
unemployment,  poverty  will  intensify  because  unemployment  allowances  benefit  only  the 
eligible unemployed in the short term and only partly replace lost income from employment. The 
slump in remittances, on which many families depend particularly for consumption, will also 
cause poverty to worsen. If GDP were to contract by 8% and remittances from immediate family 
members by 25% (and those from other remittance senders by 50%), 211,000 more people 
could fall below the poverty line, and 183,000 below the extreme poverty line, in 2009. The 
poverty rate would climb by about 6.5 percentage points in a single year, erasing the gains of 
the 3 previous years (Table 4 and Figure 7). The Summary of the Government's Poverty 
Reduction Strategy is in Appendix 2.

IV.   GOVERNMENT’S RESPONSE TO THE CRISIS 
15.  Government’s Policy Framework to Respond to the Crisis. In response to the crisis, 
the  Government  set  up  an  interministerial  crisis  management  committee  under  the  Prime 
Minister to mitigate its impacts at various levels. The Government’s policy framework is outlined 
below. This includes the IMF SBA, which replaced the PRGF and contains the Government’s 
macroeconomic framework for crisis mitigation. Under the SBA, the Government has committed 
to a range of critical reforms in monetary, exchange rate, and fiscal policies.  
 
16.  Government’s Policy Response to the Crisis 
 
•  Return to a Flexible Exchange Rate Regime. As the global financial crisis 
deepened in October 2008, the Government felt it had to intervene in exchange 
rate  policy  to  prevent  a  crisis  of  confidence  from  destabilizing  the  financial 
system.  However,  the  maintenance  of  a  soft  peg  led  to  a  large  loss  of 
international reserves and significant redollarization without dousing expectations 
of a depreciation of the dram. The Central Bank of Armenia moved to a flexible 
exchange rate in March 2009. 
 
•  Increase in Deposit Guarantee Fund Coverage. The authorities are working on 
a plan to increase the resources of the Deposit Guarantee Fund. 
 
•  Support for Macroeconomic Stability. The Government will limit the overall 
fiscal deficit in 2009 to around 6.5% of GDP, excluding unprogrammed externally 
financed  investment  projects.  The  revenue  shortfall  will  be  offset  in  part  by 
restrained spending and some tax policy measures. 
 
•  Restrictions on Non-priority Expenditure and Protection for Social Outlays. 
The  Government  will  suspend  expenditures  in  nonessential  areas  (travel, 
representation) and in areas where execution has been slow. At the same time, 
social spending on social protection programs will be protected and increased by

29.   Support for Fiscal Stimulus. The Program was prepared at the Government’s urgent 
request for support to cushion the severe impact of the crisis. It will provide budget support to 
enable  the  Government  to  meet  critical  expenditure  needs  expediently.  The  ADB  team 
considered various factors before proposing the public expenditure support option. 
 
(i)  First, regardless of the lending modality, the country needs resources to adopt 
fiscal  stimulus  measures.  Within  ADB’s  modality  of  program  lending,  the 
financing support needs to be linked as closely as possible with the reforms that 
are supported. In Armenia, much like in many other countries, the shocks are 
exogenous, and their impact has been quite severe despite the commendable 
structural reforms that Armenia has implemented over the last 5–7 years. As 
such, it is difficult to formulate policy measures that deal directly with the crisis 
and that require funds for implementation. Restoring fiscal and financial sector 
stability is one key reform area that is supported under the IMF SBA. 
 
(ii)  Second, at a time of crisis, the Government’s efforts are focused on mitigation 
and social protection. While commitment to policy and institutional reforms may 
not completely wane, human resources are likely to be stretched. Moreover, it is 
desirable that the transaction costs of any support provided by donors be kept as 
small as possible. In this regard, the team considered several other possible 
reform  areas,  including  pension  reform,  regional  development,  and  public 
financial management reforms. These, however, are medium-term efforts, which 
would need significant resources and time for satisfactory execution.  
 
(iii)  Third,  ADB  should  add  value  through  its  support.  The  proposed  public 
expenditure  option  helps  in  that  direction.  It  will  help  reinforce  measures  to 
accelerate macroeconomic recovery.

VI.  BENEFITS, IMPACT, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
41.  The Program will help the Government reduce poverty incidence and restore growth to 
its pre-crisis trajectory. It will further support the Government’s initiatives to ensure that the poor 
and vulnerable groups, who may be hit hardest by the crisis, are shielded from its adverse 
impact. It will help the Government protect and create jobs while maintaining effective social 
protection safety nets. It is anchored in the IMF SBA and thereby supports the Government’s 
macroeconomic stabilization and expenditure management plan.  
 
42.  The Program will provide specific benefits to stimulate aggregate demand. It will enable 
the Government to 
 
(i)  maintain its core public expenditure program without any cuts, over and above 
adjustments already made; 
(ii)  meet social safety net spending needs; and 
(iii)  create at least 6,500 new jobs by the end of 2009. 
 
43.  Risks. There are two main risks. First, a worsening of the global financial crisis—or its 
continuation for a period longer than anticipated—could hinder the Government’s economic 
recovery plans. As the proposed Program is within the overall IMF framework, any such adverse 
changes  in  the  external  economic  circumstances  need  to  be  mitigated  through  corrective 
economic policies as well as external support. ADB will coordinate closely with the IMF and 
other development partners in responding to any such shocks. Second, any changes in the 
political situation may weaken the Government’s ability to implement anti-crisis measures. While 
this risk is outside of ADB’s control, it is unlikely that any such changes will alter the substance 
and thrust of the anti-crisis plan per se.  
 
44.  Assumptions. It is assumed that all partners will provide timely and adequate budget 
support and technical assistance. As the Program is anchored on the IMF SBA, it is assumed 
that all the prior actions and structural benchmarks under the SBA will remain. Further, it is also 
assumed that all the Government’s own expenditure projects, as well as those supported by 
development partners, will be executed in a timely manner.

A. Links to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
 
The Government’s long-term vision is presented in detail in the Sustainable Development Program (SDP). Approved in 
October 2008, SDP is Armenia’s second Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP II) and has three key goals covering 
the period 2009–2021 (with specific medium-term targets for 2009–2015): (i) reducing poverty and eliminating extreme 
poverty; (ii) ensuring human development; and (iii) deepening economic growth and accelerating the development of 
lagging regions.  
The SDP builds on the considerable achievements of PRSP I. Armenia’s poverty and extreme poverty rates declined in 
2006 to 26.5% and 4.1% of the population, respectively (from 34.6% and 6.4%, respectively, in 2004). Inequality also 
decreased to a rate below the PRSP I goal. Prudent fiscal and monetary policies were instrumental in maintaining 
macroeconomic stability and contributing to poverty reduction. Real gross domestic product (GDP) grew by 13.1% per 
year on average over the period 2003–2007, and inflation averaged 3.9% during the same period,  while social 
expenditures increased to 4.7% of GDP, well above the projected PRSP I goal of 3.0%. Increased resources to the social 
sectors improved the access to and quality of general secondary education, and have led to improvements in overall 
utilization of and geographic access to basic health services, most notably through the free provision of primary health 
care to the population. 
However, economic diversification has been limited, with growth performance narrowly based on remittances and 
construction. Export performance has been disappointing, with real growth of less than 2% per annum in 2004–2007. The 
revenue-to-GDP ratio grew to a less-than-targeted 14.5% by 2006, reflecting limited progress in reforming revenue

The  SDP  shows  that  Armenia  plans  to  continue  its  impressive  gains  in  combating  poverty  and  inequality.  The

The SDP presents an extensive and in-depth coverage of the macroeconomic framework and of macroeconomic policies.

significant  amount  of  deposits  being  converted  to  foreign  currency,  and  overall  deposits 
declining slightly, banks came under pressure to reduce lending. In this context, and in line with 
the changed inflation outlook, the CBA eased monetary policy, cutting the policy rate from 
7.75% in November 2008 to 6.75% in February 2009. 
 
5.  As a result of the commodity price shock and our attempt to preserve financial stability, 
we  missed  most  of  the  end-December  targets  under  the  PRGF  arrangement.  Due  to

6.  The short-term economic outlook presents enormous challenges. Difficulties in many 
sectors, including mining and construction, are affecting growth prospects and weakening the 
labor market. GDP growth in 2009 is projected to fall considerably with respect to 2008, and 
unemployment  is  expected  to  increase.  Depressed  international  commodity  prices,  falling 
remittances, and weaker capital inflows are putting pressure on the balance of payments, 
despite falling domestic demand. The redollarization of the financial system presents risks for 
financial stability and challenges for monetary policy. We are expecting a gradual recovery in 
2010, but this is highly dependent on global economic developments, and downside risks are 
prevalent.  A  strong  policy  response  is  needed  to  restore  confidence,  stop  the  loss  of 
international reserves, and maintain macroeconomic stability. 
II.  THE PROGRAM FOR 2009 
7.  The policies outlined below are designed to tackle the economic and financial challenges 
now confronting Armenia. These policies, which would form the basis for a new 28-month 
stand-by arrangement from the Fund, are aimed at preserving economic and financial stability, 
while mitigating the impact of the global crisis and economic downturn on the poor. Central to 
this strategy is the return to a flexible exchange rate regime supported by appropriate monetary 
policies. We are also vigilant to possible distress in the financial sector, and will respond rapidly 
should more targeted measures be needed. A sound fiscal policy will underpin our commitment 
to macroeconomic stability, while ensuring that growth promoting public investment moves 
forward. In addition, we want to preserve the impressive gains Armenia has made in reducing 
poverty  in  recent  years.  To  this  end,  we  will  ensure  that  the  level  of  social  services  is 
maintained, and that programs to protect the poor are expanded as needed. We will continue 
our  ambitious  structural  reform  program  aimed  at  strengthening  public  finances,  boosting 
productivity, and increasing the resilience of the economy. 
 
8.  We will establish a high-level committee to monitor developments in the economy and 
coordinate the policy response of the authorities to the ongoing economic challenges. This 
committee will be chaired by the Prime Minister, and will include representatives from the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF), Ministry of Economy, the CBA, and the State Revenue Committee. 
A.  Monetary, Exchange Rate, and Financial Sector Policies 
9.  We are committed to return to a flexible exchange rate regime in the immediate future. 
Since  the  deepening  of  the  global  financial  crisis  in  October  2008,  intervention  has  been 
necessary to prevent a crisis of confidence that was threatening the stability of the financial 
system. However, we recognize that the maintenance of a soft peg has led to a large loss of 
international reserves and significant redollarization without stemming expectations of a dram 
depreciation. This, in turn, has undermined the credibility of our inflation-targeting framework 
and  the  effectiveness  of  monetary  policy,  which  we  are  committed  to  restoring.  Since 
October 2008,  our  exchange  rate  misalignment  has  increased  significantly,  owing  to  the 
worsening economic outlook and the currency depreciation experienced by many of our trade 
partners. We expect the exchange rate to move to a value in line with its fundamentals when we 
return to a floating regime. When normal market functioning is restored, our exchange rate 
policy will be a managed float with no predetermined path. We are committed to intervening only 
to smooth excessive market volatility and to increase international reserves.

10.  Monetary policy will be geared towards supporting the return to a flexible exchange rate 
regime. As outlined below, we will take any emergency measures necessary to address banks’ 
liquidity shortages in order to avoid any risks of bank runs. The CBA will raise policy interest 
rates at the time we return to a flexible regime. This will support demand for dram-denominated 
assets, fight capital outflows, mitigate any inflationary pressures stemming from depreciation, 
and restore confidence in the financial sector. Throughout this transition period, we will conduct 
an open and transparent communication campaign to explain to the public the reasons behind 
the depreciation and any additional measures needed to preserve financial stability. 
 
11.  Strengthening financial stability will be a critical part of the program: 
 
•  To  ensure  a  timely  and  consistent  policy  response,  the  CBA  will  prepare  a 
comprehensive and actionable contingency plan for the financial sector. This 
plan will contain the explicit policy responses to all likely developments, including 
liquidity shortages in the banking sector, with responsibilities of various parties 
clearly defined. The CBA will consult with the government as needed on the 
preparation of this contingency plan. 
 
•  We  recognize  that  the  banking  system  will  be  adversely  affected  by  the 
depreciation of the dram and will take all appropriate measures to ensure that 
banks remain able to meet all liabilities as they fall due. The CBA stands ready to 
provide  liquidity  to  banks  on  a  temporary  basis  in  exchange  for  adequate 
collateral. The CBA will, on a temporary basis, accept a wider range of collateral, 
including pledged fixed assets, bank shares, and high quality bank loans, if 
necessary. 
 
•  Should circumstances warrant it, the coverage of the Deposit Guarantee Fund 
will be increased. In addition, the authorities will approve a plan to increase the 
resources  of  the  Deposit  Guarantee  Fund  (performance  criterion  for 
end-June 2009). 
 
•  Bank  supervision  will  be  enhanced  with  more  intensive  on-site  and  off-site 
surveillance and monitoring. If financial conditions in any banks appear to be 
deteriorating,  we  will  agree  with  bank  management  and  shareholders  on  a 
restructuring plan to resolve the difficulties. In the first instance, we would expect 
the banks’ shareholders to recapitalize the bank to adequate levels. However, we 
will also set out a framework for using public resources if this approach proves to 
be inadequate. In exceptional cases, we will provide banks with long-term funds. 
In order to protect taxpayers’ interests, the banks will issue subordinated debt, 
with  an  option  to  convert  such  debt  into  bank  equity.  We  will  also  tighten 
prudential standards, particularly regarding foreign currency exposures, and will 
progressively work to reduce banks’ net open positions. 
 
12.  As market conditions stabilize, we will return to our inflation-targeting framework. In the 
short  term,  increased  dollarization  will  hamper  the  implementation  of  monetary  policy. 
Therefore,  it  will  be  particularly  important  to  further  strengthen  the  monetary  transmission 
mechanism,  pursue  more  active  liquidity  management,  and  foster  the  development  of  the 
money market. To enhance monetary operations and debt management, the MOF and CBA will 
closely coordinate their liquidity forecasting and MOF debt issuance to take account of both 
budget  financing  and  liquidity  management  needs.  Furthermore,  the  CBA  will  continue  to

CBA also plans to increase its holdings of treasury securities over the medium term in order to

B.  Fiscal Policy 
13.  Fiscal policy will support macroeconomic stability, while allowing for continued public 
investment and protection of social services. To this end, we intend to limit the overall fiscal 
deficit in 2009 to around 3% of GDP, excluding nonprogrammed externally-financed investment 
projects (see below). The deterioration in the deficit target relative to the 1% of GDP budget 
objective is due to the fact that revenue is projected to be significantly lower than the projection 
in  the  budget,  reflecting  the  contraction  in  economic  activity,  particularly  the  downturn  in 
revenue-generating sectors such as mining. As discussed below, the revenue shortfall will be 
offset in part by restrained spending and some tax policy measures. 
 
14.  On spending, we plan to restrict non-priority expenditure, while protecting social outlays 
and allowing for higher investment as foreign financing materializes. To this end, we expect 
substantial savings on nonessential spending and areas where execution has been slow. At the 
same time, we intend to boost spending on social protection programs, and are in discussions 
with partners, notably the World Bank, on how to strengthen these programs. 
 
15.  Our aim is to restrict spending financed by domestic resources and instead rely on 
external financing to fund the increase in capital spending. We expect additional resources to 
become available from external donors and partners on top of what is currently projected by the 
IMF. While much of these resources are only partially concessional, they would allow us to 
finance more public investment projects, and potentially set up credit lines for small and medium 
enterprises.  To  this  end,  we  propose  to  spend  up  to  $200  million  from  those  additional 
resources on public investment in 2009, which would allow us to increase our deficit target 
accordingly. We are committed to maintaining transparency in the use of such resources by 
channeling any additional spending through the budget. We will also limit the use of government 
cash deposits to finance the budget, as we recognize the need to have a cushion for cash-flow 
management purposes, and possibly for future needs. 
 
16.  We are implementing some changes to tax policy. Given the weak revenue outlook and 
the difficult conditions facing Armenian firms with respect to trading partners, we plan to raise 
temporarily customs tariffs for some goods. We recognize the distortionary impact of such a 
policy, and the negative impact on the poor. However, the changes in tariff rates are within our 
commitments to the WTO, and will be limited to a certain number of goods for which Armenian 
substitutes exist. In terms of revenue impact, we expect this measure to generate an additional 
AMD10 billion in receipts in 2009. In addition, we have recently raised presumptive taxes on 
tobacco products, we plan to raise excise taxes on imported alcoholic beverages, and are 
considering raising presumptive taxes on petroleum products. Looking forward, we maintain our 
objective of abolishing presumptive taxation for tobacco and fuel, and to this end, we will submit 
legislation to parliament by December 2009 to bring petroleum and tobacco products within the 
regular tax regimes (excise tax, customs duties, profit tax, and value-added tax [VAT]), effective 
1 January 2011.

18.  We remain committed to our ambitious tax administration reform agenda. To this end,

III.  PROGRAM FINANCING 
22.  Armenia faces significant financing needs during the program period. Our estimates 
suggest that a large financing gap in 2009 is likely, due to a significant reduction in export 
earnings, private transfers, and private capital inflows. The decline in export earnings reflects 
the sharp drop in base metals prices and weakening external demand, while the steep drop in 
private transfers and capital inflows is particularly associated with the sharp contraction of the 
Russian economy, from which the majority of both remittances and foreign direct investment 
(FDI) originate. 
 
23.  In the current global climate there are limited available sources of financing. FDI is 
projected to slow considerably in line with the expected weakening of the Russian economy, the
